description: From Middle English owen, from Old English āgan, from Proto-West Germanic *aigan (“to own”), from Proto-Germanic *aiganą, from Proto-Indo-European *h₂eh₂óyḱe (“to possess, own”), reduplicated stative of *h₂eyḱ- (“to own”). See also own, ought.
Cognate with Sanskrit ईष्टे (īṣṭe, “to own, possess”).

verbs.description: owe (third-person singular simple present owes, present participle owing, simple past owed or (archaic) ought, past participle owed or (archaic) own)

entries.meaning: (ditransitive) To be under an obligation to give something back to someone or to perform some action for someone.
examples: I owe Kevin five bucks which he lent to me last week.
This time I'll cover for you, but now you owe me a favour.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have debt; to be in debt.
(transitive) To have as a cause; used with to.
examples: The record owes its success to the outstanding guitar solos.
